instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage no image
threads.message:
This is a strange one.
Wine on the keyboard (classic).
No corrosion on the motherboard.
Replaced keyboard.
Screen has no image, no backlight.
Image flashes for a milisecond on chime and goes away.
Tested with new screen. Good image. Tested old screen on another macbook -> Good image. 
No voltage on lcd connector pins. L8304 jumps to 3V for a milisecond and disappears. 
Is it screen or motherboard problem?

Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage no image
threads.message: Just swap the screens and problem solved? I would assume a bad LCD or cable. Possibly crap on IO board/cable so <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is pulled low?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage no image
threads.message:
Yeah but for a customer its a really expensive solution :D I was just wondering if there would be an alternative solution. I removed the display bezel and looked at io board and replaced lcd cable but still same problem. So I guess new screen is the only solution then.

THanks.
